issue_description:
# Port all `core` templates to Django template syntax

Some templates in our `core` app currently use Backbone.js template syntax.

## Task

Port the following template from Backbone to Django view/template syntax.

all templates in `core` app should
- [ ] work without any JavaScript (Backbone.js)
- [ ] use only Django template syntax, such as `{% for solution in solutions %}`

all templates in `core` app should not contain any
- [ ] Backbone.js template syntax, such as `{{# _.each(solutions, function (s) { }}`
- [ ] `verbatim` tags
- [ ] `backbone_templates` block content

issue_comments.body: Hi, I would like to work on this issue over the weekend. Please assign it to me.
You can start working on it. üëç
@dayitachaudhuri, thanks for taking on this task! I'm available to help if you have any questions or difficulties.
I'll also love to work on this if this issue is still open ... please let me know if it is available
@dayitachaudhuri is currently assigned to this task.
I will wait in line to work on this issue. If still open, kindly assign it to me. Thanks.

Hello, @brylie. I don't really have significant understanding of js templating, so I don't understand what it is trying to return. So, I am a little bit stuck in this section. For example, in this part where we need to remove the js templating syntax, I have tried fixing it with Django templating syntax but I feel everything is just very wrong...haha below is a sample part I am trying to fix, and after the comment is my solution
![Screenshot (414)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87471613/215533433-52fcdbe0-8fa5-43d6-a973-d572ff01f289.png)
.

The code is a for loop that renders a partial template with some data. Just copy the markup from the `notification-item-template` into the loop body in place of the call to `cw.underscorePartial`. From there, it should be more apparent where to use the Django `for` loop and `if` statements.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.1/ref/templates/builtins/#for 

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.1/ref/templates/builtins/#if 

This might be a good use case for the `for...empty` loop.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.1/ref/templates/builtins/#for-empty

![Otek](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87471613/215848784-854d7987-b87a-48f0-bacc-d2a63df121a5.png)
However, the same file in my branch looks so different, and it is this
![Screenshot (416)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87471613/215849034-92742e0a-f1eb-4e21-b731-ee28a6e30f3f.png)

https://github.com/CiviWiki/OpenCiviWiki/commit/98fb90db66e5f69009182c9f3e553eee4f04d9a0

Hello @brylie. I made a new PR. If there are more issues, then I will surely need some guidelines to fix them properly. Thaks
[2a55488](https://github.com/CiviWiki/OpenCiviWiki/commit/2a55488c08158a99d86c1f5ca5ed5a2e1dfcef3e)
Hey, @brylie. I just realized that there may be an issue with my PR. I mean, there needs to be only a single block of content in each file. I think my last PR might also have an issue.
Hey @brylie. I made the necessary changes here [ac3a41b](https://github.com/CiviWiki/OpenCiviWiki/commit/ac3a41b063de466b32f1273ce0487adc271fcca4)
Hey @brylie I made the changes in this new PR. [fb7e2d1](https://github.com/CiviWiki/OpenCiviWiki/commit/fb7e2d1550fb25ec269cfbb485be54d3f1b6c2c6)

text_context:
# Port all `core` templates to Django template syntax

Some templates in our `core` app currently use Backbone.js template syntax.

## Task

Port the following template from Backbone to Django view/template syntax.

all templates in `core` app should
- [ ] work without any JavaScript (Backbone.js)
- [ ] use only Django template syntax, such as `{% for solution in solutions %}`

all templates in `core` app should not contain any
- [ ] Backbone.js template syntax, such as `{{# _.each(solutions, function (s) { }}`
- [ ] `verbatim` tags
- [ ] `backbone_templates` block content

Hi, I would like to work on this issue over the weekend. Please assign it to me.

You can start working on it. üëç 

@dayitachaudhuri, thanks for taking on this task! I'm available to help if you have any questions or difficulties.

I'll also love to work on this if this issue is still open ... please let me know if it is available

@dayitachaudhuri is currently assigned to this task.

I will wait in line to work on this issue. If still open, kindly assign it to me. Thanks.

Hello, @brylie. I don't really have significant understanding of js templating, so I don't understand what it is trying to return. So, I am a little bit stuck in this section. For example, in this part where we need to remove the js templating syntax, I have tried fixing it with Django templating syntax but I feel everything is just very wrong...haha below is a sample part I am trying to fix, and after the comment is my solution
![Screenshot (414)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87471613/215533433-52fcdbe0-8fa5-43d6-a973-d572ff01f289.png)
.


The code is a for loop that renders a partial template with some data. Just copy the markup from the `notification-item-template` into the loop body in place of the call to `cw.underscorePartial`. From there, it should be more apparent where to use the Django `for` loop and `if` statements.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.1/ref/templates/builtins/#for 

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.1/ref/templates/builtins/#if 

This might be a good use case for the `for...empty` loop.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/4.1/ref/templates/builtins/#for-empty

{% blocktranslate %} At CiviWiki we believe democracy works best when citizens are educated on issues and participate in the democratic process. We are a non-profit, non-partisan, community; working to build an open-source platform where citizens discuss the problems they face, discover solutions, and enact change. {% endblocktranslate %}




{% translate "Check out our short video describing CiviWiki..." %}

{% translate "Video made by" %} Jon Sheldon

{% translate "Why CiviWiki?" %}

group

{% translate "Democratically Contributed Media" %}

{% blocktranslate %} As the name CiviWiki implies, our core content will be contributed by volunteers on our Wiki. Our topic format is modular. The structure both allows a community of volunteers to collaborate on a single political issue, and reserves space for dissenting opinions. {% endblocktranslate %}

{% translate "Personalized Policy Feed" %}

{% blocktranslate %} CiviWiki intelligently personalizes users' feed in two meaningful ways. First, the issues promoted to users' feed will be personalized to the user's expressed interests, and the timeliness of the issue. Second, the structure of the issue topics break policy positions into bite-sized contentions we call Civies. Each Civi is logically related to the rest of the topic. Based on the user's support, opposition, or neutrality to each Civi, CiviWiki promotes different relevant content {% endblocktranslate %}

questions_generated: What is the main task outlined in the issue for the CiviWiki_OpenCiviWiki repository?
Why is it important for the templates in the 'core' app to work without any JavaScript?
What specific changes are suggested for converting Backbone.js template syntax to Django template syntax?
What difficulties might arise from removing JavaScript templating syntax and how can they be addressed?
How could the use of 'verbatim' tags in Django templates conflict with the task requirements?
What does the discussion suggest as a first step in porting the template syntax from Backbone.js to Django?
golden_answers_generated: The main task is to port all templates in the 'core' app from Backbone.js template syntax to Django template syntax. The templates should work without any JavaScript, use only Django template syntax, and should not contain Backbone.js template syntax, 'verbatim' tags, or 'backbone_templates' block content.

The requirement for templates to work without JavaScript ensures that the application remains functional even if JavaScript is disabled or not supported in a user's browser. This enhances accessibility and ensures that content is rendered using server-side logic rather than relying on client-side scripts.

The changes involve replacing Backbone.js syntax like `{{# _.each(solutions, function (s) { }}` with Django's template syntax such as `{% for solution in solutions %}`. This includes using Django's `for`, `if`, and possibly `for...empty` statements to handle loops and conditions.

One difficulty might be understanding how JavaScript templating logic translates to Django's server-side rendering. This can be addressed by understanding the data flow and logic in the JavaScript templates, then using Django's template language to achieve the same logic. Documentation and examples of Django's template syntax can be helpful in this process.

The use of 'verbatim' tags in Django templates allows raw template syntax to be included without being processed by Django. This would conflict with the task requirements because it would mean that parts of the template are not following the pure Django syntax, which is necessary for the task of eliminating JavaScript dependencies and using Django's rendering engine exclusively.

The discussion suggests copying the markup from the `notification-item-template` into the loop body in place of the call to `cw.underscorePartial`, which would help clarify where to use Django's `for` loop and `if` statements. This step-by-step replacement can help in understanding the translation from JavaScript templating to Django's templating language.
